ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.
M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: How much more or less do you feel you worry about your weight and body shape than other girls/women your age?
Notes: 1 = I worry a lot less than other girls/women; 2 = I worry a little less than other girls/women; 3 = I worry about the same as other girls/women; 4 = I worry a little more than other girls/women; 5 = I worry a lot more than other girls/women; 999 = Missing

ElementDescription: How afraid are you of gaining 3 pounds?
Notes: 1 = Not afraid of gaining; 2 = Slightly afraid of gaining; 3 = Moderately afraid of gaining; 4 = Very afraid of gaining; 5 = Terrified of gaining; 999 = Missing

ElementDescription: When was the last time you went on a diet?
Notes: 1 = I've never been on a diet; 2 = I was on a diet about 1 year ago; 3 = I was on a diet about 6 months ago; 4 = I was on a diet about 3 months ago; 5 = I was on a diet about 1 month ago; 6 = I was on a diet less than 1 month ago; 7 = I'm now on a diet; 999 = Missing

ElementDescription: Compared to other things in your life, how important is your weight to you?
Notes: 1 = My weight is not important compared to other things in my life; 2 = My weight is a little more important than some other things; 3 = My weight is more important than most, but not all, things in my life; 4 = My weight is the most important thing in my life; 999 = Missing
1 = Never; 2 = Rarely; 3 = Sometimes; 4 = Often; 5 = Always; 999 = Missing

Sum and average the five scores: [100 x (wcs_1 - 1) / 4], [100 x (wcs_2 - 1) / 4], [100 x (wcs_3 - 1) / 6], [100 x (wcs_4 - 1) / 3], [100 x (wcs_5 - 1) / 4]. Scores above 52 are associated with an increased risk of developing an eating disorder within 4 years
